title.value: Cardiomyocyte orientation recovery at micrometer scale reveals long-axis fiber continuum in heart walls
title.justification: The title directly reflects the core focus of the paper, which is the recovery of cardiomyocyte orientation at a micrometer scale to reveal fiber continuum in heart walls.
title.quote: Cardiomyocyte orientation recovery at micrometer scale reveals long-axis fiber continuum in heart walls

extractions.description: This paper presents a novel approach combining microscopy and computer vision to reconstruct the three-dimensional orientation of cardiomyocytes across mouse heart ventricular walls at micrometer scale, significantly enhancing spatial resolution and contributing to the understanding of heart mechanics and electrical function.

type.justification: The paper describes the development and application of novel imaging and analysis techniques to obtain empirical, high-resolution reconstructions of cardiomyocyte orientations.
type.quote: By combining microscopy and computer vision, we produced the first-ever three-dimensional cardiomyocyte orientation reconstruction across mouse ventricular walls at the micrometer scale.

name.justification: The research involves computational techniques to analyze biological data, specifically using computer vision and imaging methods to study cellular structures in biology.
name.quote: To tackle this problem, we developed new tissue structure orientation analysis methods by combining confocal light microscopy-based deep and wide imaging with computer vision techniques.

name.justification: The study focuses on the microstructure of cardiomyocytes within the heart, directly related to the cardiovascular system's function and mechanics.
name.quote: Coordinated cardiomyocyte contraction drives the mammalian heart to beat and circulate blood.

name.justification: The study uses advanced microscopy techniques to achieve high-resolution imaging necessary for cardiomyocyte orientation analysis.
name.quote: Micron-scale light microscopy methods have the potential to recover orientation at the scale of individual cardiomyocytes.
